perturbation.original_text: Licensor shall provide to Rogers at least ninety (90) days prior notice of the availability date of any Licensed Program added to such list during the Term; (ii) Licensor shall provide to Rogers at least sixty (60) days prior notice of the deletion of any Licensed Program from such list; and (iii) Licensor shall be responsible for any and all reasonable costs and/or losses incurred by Rogers as a result of any deletions from such list during the Term.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensor shall provide to Rogers at least fifteen (15) days prior notice of the availability date of any Licensed Program added to such list during the Term; (ii) Licensor shall provide to Rogers at least five (5) days prior notice of the deletion of any Licensed Program from such list; and (iii) Licensor shall not be responsible for any costs and/or losses incurred by Rogers as a result of any deletions from such list during the Term.
perturbation.explanation: Reduced notice periods for availability and deletion of licensed programs, and removing the responsibility for costs associated with deletion. These modifications are designed to conflict with industry standards and potentially reasonable business practices, increasing risk for Rogers. Notice periods are unreasonably short.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of good faith and fair dealing in contract law.

perturbation.original_text: Payment of License Fees shall be made in Canadian funds in arrears within thirty (30) days following each calendar month during the Term in which Licensed Programs were exhibited hereunder and shall be accompanied by a statement of account showing the calculation of the License Fees.
perturbation.changed_text: Payment of License Fees shall be made at Licensor's discretion and without a statement of account.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the obligation to pay within a defined timeframe and eliminates the requirement for a statement of account. This conflicts with basic contract law principles requiring clear payment terms.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Basic principles of contract law regarding payment terms and enforceability.

perturbation.original_text: Any Notice given pursuant to this Agreement shall make specific reference to this Agreement. Any Notice so given shall be deemed to have been received on the date on which it was delivered in person, or transmitted, if delivered or transmitted on a day, other than a Saturday, on which the Toronto-Dominion Bank in Toronto is open for business (a "Business Day") during normal business hours of the recipient and, if not so delivered or transmitted, on the next Business Day or, if sent by registered mail, on the fifth (5t h) Business Day thereafter; provided, however, that either party may change its address and/or facsimile number for purposes of receipt of any such communication by giving ten (10) days prior written notice of such change to the other party in the manner prescribed above.
perturbation.changed_text: Any Notice given pursuant to this Agreement may be delivered by any means, and is deemed to have been received immediately, regardless of the method of delivery. Email notifications are sufficient and legally binding.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a structured notification framework, while the modified version permits any form of communication, even if unreliable, and deems it immediately received, conflicting with legal principles of providing sufficient notice and proof of delivery. The elimination of physical delivery options also creates enforceability issues under traditional contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles relating to notice, delivery, and proof of service.
